node.title: BlockSubdomainModifier?
node.bodyText:
Dear Community,
Following the procedure recommended here, I would like to propose a "BlockSubdomainModifier" for discussion.
Motivation and current situation
With the group of "XYZSubdomainModifiers" Moose provides a tool to re-assign elements to different subdomains (blocks) during an simulation run. In tensor mechanis, this approach might be used to model the removal/excavation and refill. For geometrical complex models, the most efficient way defining the volumes to be excavated/refilled might be defined by means of subdomains. This leads to the task of moving whole blocks from one subdomain to another at pre-known points in time in a Moose-model. For this purpose the use of a CoupledVarThresholdElementSubdomainModifier is shown in #26941.
As shown in #26941, to just move one block once to another subdomain a Moose input file needs at least an AuxVariable, an FunctionAux, and a CoupledVarThresholdElementSubdomainModifier. Naïvely one could argue, it takes 36 lines of code to reassign a single block once to another subdomain - which is a source of error on its own. In geotechnical or mining applications it is necessary to reassign several blocks during one simulation.
Proposed BlockSubdomainModifier
To ease re-assignment, make Moose input files shorter, and reduce potential sources of error I'd like to propose an BlockSubdomainModifier. The BlockSubdomainModifier inherits from ElementSubdomainModifier (and therefore inheriting also the handling of the boundaries). The new UserObject takes a path to a CSV formates file containing the information on when to move which block where. Therefore, only one UserObject will be needed for all block reassignments in a given model.
Snipped of the input file using the proposed BlockSubdomainModifier:
[UserObjects]
  [BlockSubdomainModifier1]
    type = BlockSubdomainModifier
    file_name = 'stages-tab.csv'
    header = 'ON'
    execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_BEGIN'
  []
[]

The corresponding CSV-File may contain a header and 3 columns (time, source-subdomain, and destination-subdomain):
time,   BlockFrom,  BlockTo
0.40,   Box1,       8
0.20,   Box2,       8
0.60,   8,          Box1

As can be seen in the CSV above, also subdomain-names are permissible (to improve readability and debugging). To allow for this, this proposal also includes the implementation of the DelimitedFileReaderOfString which is copied from the DelimitedFileReader (and removed all the stuff connected to conversion to double).
Impact to existing Moose apps
As this proposal only adds functionality and does not change any existing code, existing Moose apps should be able to cope with the proposed changes without any problems.
I would be delighted if you could consider this proposal.
Edit Please find the code here including:

BlockSubdomainModifier.C
DelimitedFileReaderOfString.C

Hello
We'll want @hugary1995 's opinion on this and possibly @lindsayad for awareness / re-direction to other stakeholders at least.
Maybe @dschwen ?
These are good ideas overall and I think you have figured out a lot of the implementation already.
One problem is the name. A block is the same as a subdomain so a BlockSubdomainModifier is not something that is easily understandable.
Given the design I would say: TimedSubdomainModifier.
This conveys well that there are no other decision criteria on when to change the mesh. Also since there's "Element" in the name, it s understood that entire subdomains will change at once.
I can see simple input parameters as an alternative to the CSV file for simple problems. And for your large problem, use the CSV file option.
Guillaume
This seems reasonable to me

Dear @GiudGiud,
I am happy about the positive feedback so far.
For the naming:
Agreed, TimedSubdomainModifier describes the UserObject more meaningfully and better.
Simple input parameters as an alternative to the CSV:
I assume that the TimedSubdomainModifier should then behave in the same way as PiecewiseConstant (having xy_data and data_file), for example? Not by means of a TimedSubdomainModifier (taking the data directly via parameter) and a TimedSubdomainModifierCSV using a CSV file?
Jörg

Hello
Piecewise constant is an example of a dual input object yes.
I would prefer splitting the parameters for the input file parameters.
So 3 vector parameters
Old blocks
New blocks
Block_swap_time
It s more readable imo
Guillaume

This sounds like a great idea to me, and the proposed design seems reasonable to me.
Adding to @GiudGiud 's suggestion, I'd like to see part of the proposed capability moved into an intermediate class. So, instead of a concrete TimedSubdomainModifier, I suggest you create an intermediate abstract class called TimedElementSubdomainModifier, which doesn't perform the actual job. Add an additional input parameter times or target_times in TimedElementSubdomainModifier. All the logic related to target times should go into this intermediate class. For example, we should allow users to specify the target times with a vector, i.e. target_times = '0.2 0.4 0.6'. Once you have this intermediate class, let the existing ThresholdElementSubdomainModifier inherit from it, so that the new capability you add will also benefit all the existing modifiers.
The inheritance diagram I'm imagining (could be improved, for sure) is
                  ElementSubdomainModifier
                             |
                 TimedElementSubdomainModifier
                        |              |  
ThresholdElementSubdomainModifier    CSVSubdomainModifier
              |
CoupledVarThresholdElementSubdomainModifier

Dear all,
Thank you, @GiudGiud, @lindsayad, and @hugary1995 for the positive feedback!
Following the suggestions of @GiudGiud and @hugary1995 I've created a new branch: TimedSubdomainModifier
The changes are:

The user object is now called TimedSubdomainModifier .h-file -c-file
The TimedSubdomainModifier now inherits of the newly created TimedElementSubdomainModifier .h-file .c-file
The TimedSubdomainModifier now has properties to provide the times ans blocks directly in the input file -or- via file name using a CSV file. Please see below.
The TimedElementSubdomainModifier does some work related to the timestamps (sorting them, providing t_from_exclusive and t_to_inclusive for the function onComputeSubdomainID
The DelimitedFileReaderOfString remains unchanged .h-file  .c-file
Blocks may be given via id or name (applies to the vector parameters and the CSV as well) to ease readability and model debugging.

With this changes the usage of the TimedSubdomainModifier looks like:
[UserObjects]
    [SubdomainModifier1]
      type = TimedSubdomainModifier
      times       = '0.4  0.2 '
      blocks_from = 'Box1 Box2'
      blocks_to   = '8    8   '
      execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_BEGIN'
    []
[]

Or like this:
[UserObjects]
    [SubdomainModifier1]
      type = TimedSubdomainModifier
      data_file = 'stages-tab.csv'
      header = 'ON'
      execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_BEGIN'
    []
[]

What do you think?

Hello
user interface looks great. Will you make a PR to contribute your work to MOOSE? I can review the code then
Guillaume

Dear @GiudGiud,
Please find my PR here: #27092
Kind regards,
Jörg

node.title: Optimizing material parameters using postprocessor values
node.bodyText:
Dear All,
I am looking for a way to fit a simulated stress-strain curve to an experimental stress-strain curve by optimizing material parameters. I saw that the Optimization module has examples on material inversion, however, they optimize point-based values and I didn't see anything that would work with postprocessor (global) values.
My use-case would be a crystal plasticity simulation. For example, CrystalPlasticityKalidindiUpdate material model. I know all parameters, except exponent n and preexponent gammaDot0. At each timestep two postprocessors calculate global average stress and strain. I want to compare these calculated stress-strain values to experimental stress-strain values. Then, change the exponent and preexponent material parameters to minimize the error between simulated-experimental stress-strain values. Is something like this possible using the Optimization module?
Best regards
Andris

I would look at this example: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/optimization/examples/shapeOpt_Annulus.html
Ignore the parts about the constraints, but given a postprocessor that is your objective value, you can use the derivative free nelder-mead, or the finite-differencing gradient option to optimize the parameters to get you the lowest postprocessor value.

node.title: Applying Main App Adaptive Mesh to Sub App in MultiApp
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE experts,
I'm currently working on transfer adaptive mesh refinement from a main application into a sub-application within a MultiApp. We found that LevelSetMeshRefinementTransfer can meet such requirements, but it is located in the level set module instead of the moose module. Based on the provided reference calculation example (parent.i), I wrote my own calculation example file.
However, upon implementing a similar setup in our custom application, we've encountered an issue where the mesh adaptivity does not seem to be executed within the sub-application. Additionally, as shown in the attached image,

the markers intended for transfer do not appear to be successfully replicated in the sub-app.
I'm seeking guidance on the following points:

Could there be specific considerations or settings that I might have overlooked in applying LevelSetMeshRefinementTransfer to ensure successful mesh refinement and marker transfer to the sub-app?
Is the Level Set Module's LevelSetMeshRefinementTransfer inherently applicable to other apps, or are there strategies to generalize its application for use with other MOOSE-based Apps?

Any insights, suggestions, or references to similar cases would be immensely appreciated. Our goal is to effectively leverage MOOSE's capabilities for our project, and resolving this issue is crucial for our progress.
Thank you in advance for your support and guidance.
Best regards,
Wei

Hello
Can you transfer the marker on timestep-begin? Then execute adaptivity during the time step.
I think the timing of execution is the challenging part here
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume,
Thank you for your suggestion regarding the timing of marker transfer and adaptivity execution. Following your advice, I attempted to configure the execution of the MultiApp to occur at both timestep_begin and timestep_end to see if it would facilitate the successful transfer of markers into the sub-app. Unfortunately, this adjustment did not lead to the markers being executed within the sub-application as intended.
Further investigation into the issue revealed some additional insights. I inserted breakpoints within the LevelSetMeshRefinementTransfer code to monitor its execution flow. Through this method, I observed that LevelSetMeshRefinementTransfer::initialSetup() is being called and executed as expected. However, LevelSetMeshRefinementTransfer::execute(), which is crucial for the actual transfer of adaptivity information, does not seem to be triggered at all. This observation contrasts with the behavior seen in the reference example (parent.i), where LevelSetMeshRefinementTransfer::execute() is executed effectively.
Moreover, I encountered a limitation regarding the execution_on parameter within the LevelSetMeshRefinementTransfer. It appears that this parameter is private to LevelSetMeshRefinementTransfer and thus cannot be explicitly set in the input file.
Given these observations, it seems we are facing a more complex challenge related to the execution mechanism of the LevelSetMeshRefinementTransfer. Any further insights or recommendations on how to ensure the execute() method is triggered appropriately would be greatly appreciated.
Thank you once again for your support and for helping to steer the investigation in the right direction.
Best regards,
Wei

Hello
I dont think we need the levelset mesh refinement transfer to transfer markers but I may be wrong. I thought I saw a different post last year transfering a marker with a regular transfer. Do you really want an exact synchronization of the two meshes or can they be offset by one time step?

Moreover, I encountered a limitation regarding the execution_on parameter within the LevelSetMeshRefinementTransfer. It appears that this parameter is private to LevelSetMeshRefinementTransfer and thus cannot be explicitly set in the input file.

This may be. I can imagine we only use this transfer during rounds of adaptivity for the main app. I checked and the execution flags are hard set to:
{LevelSet::EXEC_COMPUTE_MARKERS, LevelSet::EXEC_ADAPT_MESH};

so to execute it, you need to make sure the adaptivity is active in the main app. Maybe force it to run with minimum iteration parameters if that's available?
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume,
Thank your very much for your enthusiastic help. Below is my reply to your suggestions,

I thought I saw a different post last year transfering a marker with a regular transfer.

You mean we use a regular method to transfer a marker and then run adaptivity in the sub-app, right? hugary1995 does this by directly transferring the variable used to evaluate the error in ref1 and ref2.

Do you really want an exact synchronization of the two meshes or can they be offset by one time step?

I believe  the correct approach is to initially run the main-app, followed by the transferring the mark information to the sub-app. Subsequently, we should transfer the relevent data to the sub-app, enabling the sub-app's mesh configuration aligns with that of the main-app.

so to execute it, you need to make sure the adaptivity is active in the main app. Maybe force it to run with minimum iteration parameters if that's available?

Yeah, I can confirm that the adaptivity mesh is executed at each time step in the main app, but LevelSetMeshRefinementTransfer::execute() is not found to be called in the sub-app. Also, in #18813, @aeslaughter said, "I created LevelSetMeshRefinementTransfer 5 years ago for this same concept. There might be a better way to do it now, but if not you can take a look at it for some inspiration." Perhaps he can provide more detailed advice.
In general, there are two idea. One is to directly transfer variables (e.g. bnds) based on hugary1995's methodl, and other is to use LevelSetMeshRefinementTransfer. I think the latter method is the best method, but there are still some issues to address. This necessitates further guidance for you and aeslaughter.
Wei

I can look into why the example does not execute the transfer as expected.
Could you please reduce the calculation example file down to a MOOSE-only minimal example?
Hi Guillaume, I have reduced the the calculation example file down to a MOOSE-only minimal example.

Thanks!
I m looking at the transfer but you should look at this error I hit using the devel version of the executable:

node.title: Flow reversal problem
node.bodyText:
Hi, I am trying to simulate a conjugate heat transfer problem with the time-dependent mass flow rate in a pipe with m1, m2, and m3 mass flow rates in different periods of simulation.
m1 and m3 being finite positive values and m2 is 0. Attached is the script.
The issue is when the mass flow is reduced to 0, the center line velocity reduces to a negative value and so does the temperature. The figures are attached.
It would be helpful if anyone could take a look at my script and point out the issue in it or suggest some checks to perform.
Thanks
Simulation_main.txt
Mesh.txt

@joshuahansel Could you help us with this test setup when you get a chance? @abhi1587 is seeing a decrease in solid temperature even when the fluid flow is turned off, and we suspect it's coming from the negative velocity. Thanks.

I'm sorry, I started to look at your input and then ran into some VSCode issues and moved to something else while that was getting worked out.
Could you try a larger number of axial elements than 3? 100 would be nice. I realize you may have convergence issues because of your 3D heat structure coupling not having full Jacobians. While troubleshooting, can you switch to a 2D cylindrical heat structure. That'll converge nicely. Here's an example:
moose/modules/thermal_hydraulics/test/tests/components/heat_transfer_heat_structure_1phase/phy.T_wall_transfer_3eqn_x.i

I suspect this is maybe caused by boundary conditions too close to each other and fighting, plus maybe the equation of state you're using, which I'm not super familiar with. Second step would be to change that to something else.
Thanks, Joshua. Changing the equation of state solved the issue. I will look into the documentation for how are these models affecting the solution.

node.title: How to solve the gradient of the Userobject object and introduce it into the kernel ConservativeAdvection？
node.bodyText:
I am a newbie in the field of MOOSE and C+.
After importing the Userobject into the kernel object, how do I find the gradient of the object?
'''params.addRequiredParam("convolution", "RadialGreensConvolution user object");
...
_convolution(getUserObject("convolution").getConvolution())
'''
The governing equation is ∇∙(n * ∇C),  n is Density field to be solved， C is scalar field associated with n，Get its value using RadialGreensConvolution from module magpie。
I looked at the GenericFunctorGradientMaterial.h/C file and Function.h/C. I don’t know if I can directly use the gradient() method to get the gradient. If so, how should I do it?

Hello
A user object isn't a field. You could implement a gradient routine on it but it s probably not the right option.
Is the field you want the gradient for a variable? A material property ?
Guillaume

Thanks for your reply
It is a material property calculated from variables。
Do you mean that I can convert the userobject object into material and then calculate the gradient of material?
##in the Magpie

the property is calculated by UserObject-RadialGreensConvolution。 I want to calculate the gradient of convolution and and introduce the results into the kernel

Hello
I would add a new routine to this user object that computed this gradient
Then in the kernel you use getUserObject (a fe_problem routine) templated with the specific type of this user object to retrieve a pointer to this user object. From this pointer you can call the gradient routine
Guillaume
Thank you so much！！！

Hello,Dr.Guillaume
I want to know how long it will take to complete the work.
I need to use this gradient to further develop my kernel
taozhang
If you are comfortable with C++ less than a day

node.title: Mesh issue: higher order U using a Cubit mesh in THM coupling
node.bodyText:
Hi, I am trying to use a second-order displacement with first-order pressure and temperature in my mesh. This is the part of the input file I use. It is OK with meshes generated by MOOSE's generated mesh, but it gives me this weird shape when I do this with Cubit's generated mesh. It assumes zero for values where displacement exists but p and T don't. Can you help me specify this to avoid this issue? Thanks.
just doing second_order = true  results in this issue. even without order = SECOND.
Is it something I should do with Cubit? or some other specification I need to do in the input file?
I believe that it is not a visualization issue. MOOSE is confusing the file mesh. if it was just a visualization issue, the displacements should been correct but displacement results are also meaningless. So, I guess there is an issue with how I specify the input file.
[Mesh]
  type = FileMesh
  file = fiveBores.e

  second_order = true

[Variables]

  []

  [disp_x]
    family = LAGRANGE
    order = SECOND

*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "MOOSE Problem", of type "FEProblem".
Material property 'strain_increment', requested by 'small_stress' is not defined on block bar_1
Material property 'rotation_increment', requested by 'small_stress' is not defined on block bar_1
Material property 'strain_increment', requested by 'small_stress_face' is not defined on block bar_1
Material property 'rotation_increment', requested by 'small_stress_face' is not defined on block bar_1
Material property 'strain_increment', requested by 'small_stress_neighbor' is not defined on block bar_1
Material property 'rotation_increment', requested by 'small_stress_neighbor' is not defined on block bar_1

Why did you select         incremental = true?
@GiudGiud
I also based my code on that example.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/ComputeThermalExpansionEigenstrain.html
(modules/solid_mechanics/test/tests/thermal_expansion/constant_expansion_coeff.i)

Yeah this makes sense.
Thoughts @bwspenc on why displacement is 2x the analytical ?

@eduardogrodriguez89 is the mesh converged?
If you add uniform refine = 1 in the mesh block does the result change

The mesh converged.
I added uniform refine = 1 to the mesh block and I got the same result.

I have done more simulations and a question has arisen.
In the postprocessor block, I have asked to display the eigenstrain_xx and the strain_xx. Since the example is only thermal, shouldn't the eigenstrain_xx be equal to strain_xx? Because I visualize that both are different.
thermal_eigenstrain = $\alpha  (T-T_{stress})$ $~~~~~~ \alpha$ = 12e-6  1/ºC , $(T-T_{stress})=30ºC$
thermal_eigenstrain = 3.600000e-04
Any recommendations with the code?

Postprocessor Values:
+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+
| time           | disp_x_p2      | eigenstrain_xx | p1             | strain_xx      | strain_yy      | stress_xx      | stress_yy      | temperature    |
+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+

|   3.000000e+00 |   4.680000e-03 |   3.600000e-04 |   0.000000e+00 |   4.680000e-04 |   4.680000e-04 |   4.952610e-07 |  -1.593754e-08 |   3.000000e+01 |
+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+----------------+

eigenstrain_xx = 3.600000e-04
strain_xx = 4.680000e-04

[Mesh]
  [bar]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    nx = 500
    ny=5
    ymax=0.1
    xmax = 10 
    dim = 2
  []
[]
[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
[]
[AuxVariables]
  [temp]
    initial_condition = 0.0
  []
  [eigenstrain_xx]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
[]
[Functions]
  [temperature_load]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression ='10.0*(t+0)'
  []
[]
[Physics]
  [SolidMechanics]
    [QuasiStatic]
      [all]
        strain = SMALL
        add_variables = true
        eigenstrain_names = eigenstrain
        generate_output = 'strain_xx stress_xx strain_yy stress_yy'
      []
    []
  []
[]
[AuxKernels]
  [tempfuncaux]
    type = FunctionAux
    variable = temp
    function = temperature_load
  []
  [eigenstrain_xx]
    type = RankTwoAux
    rank_two_tensor = eigenstrain
    variable = eigenstrain_xx
    index_i = 0
    index_j = 0
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  []
[]
[BCs]
  [point1_x]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = left
    value = 0.0
  []
[]
[Materials]
  [elasticity_tensor_1]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = 200e9
    poissons_ratio = 0.3
  []  
  [small_stress]
    type = ComputeLinearElasticStress
  []
  [thermal_expansion_strain_1]
    type = ComputeThermalExpansionEigenstrain
    stress_free_temperature = 0
    thermal_expansion_coeff = 12e-6
    temperature = temp
    eigenstrain_name = eigenstrain
  []
[]
[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = 'newton'
  #line_search = none
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu'
  l_max_its = 4
  l_tol = 1e-12
  nl_max_its = 30
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-8
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-10
  start_time = 0.0
  end_time = 3
  dt = 0.1
  dtmin = 0.1
[]
[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]
[Postprocessors]
  [strain_xx]
    type = ElementAverageValue
    variable = strain_xx
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  []
  [strain_yy]
    type = ElementAverageValue
    variable = strain_yy
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  []
  [stress_xx]
    type = ElementAverageValue
    variable = stress_xx
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  []
  [stress_yy]
    type = ElementAverageValue
    variable = stress_yy
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  []
  [disp_x_p2]
    type = PointValue
    point = '10 0 0'
    variable = disp_x
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  []
  [p1]
    type = PointValue
    point = '0 0 0'
    variable = disp_x
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  []
  [temperature]
    type = AverageNodalVariableValue
    variable = temp
  []
  [eigenstrain_xx]
    type = ElementAverageValue
    variable = eigenstrain_xx
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  []
[]
@dschwen knows about eigenstrains
@eduardogrodriguez89  You forgot the Poisson's ratio. The thermal strain is volumetric and you need to consider the Poisson's effect.   You can set poisson ratio = 0.0 to verify.
It works. Thanks
